question: On which date was the International Monetary Fund (IMF) officially established?
solution:
• The International Monetary Fund (IMF) was formally established on December 27, 1945, according to the International Monetary Fund. This date marks the formal constitution of the organization after its conception at the Bretton Woods Conference in July 1944.
  • It was created based on the recommendations of the Bretton Woods Conference (1944).
  • The conference aimed to establish a framework for global monetary cooperation post World War II.
  • India is one of the founding members of the IMF.
  • The IMF began its financial operations in 1947.

question: Where is the headquarters of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) located?
solution:
• The headquarters of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) is located in Washington D.C., USA.
  • It serves as the central hub for IMF operations and governance.
  • Most major decisions regarding global monetary policies are taken at this location.
  • Washington D.C. is also home to the headquarters of the World Bank, making it a key city for international financial institutions.

question: How many member countries does the International Monetary Fund (IMF) currently have? (July 2025)
solution:
• The International Monetary Fund (IMF) currently has 190 member countries.
  • Membership is open to any country that conducts foreign policy and monetary transactions.
  • Andorra became the 190th member of the IMF on 16th October 2020.
  • India is a founding member of the IMF.

question: Which organization publishes the ‚ÄúWorld Economic Outlook‚Äù report?
solution:
• The World Economic Outlook is published by the International Monetary Fund (IMF).
  • It is released twice a year‚Äîin April and October, with interim updates in January and July.
  • The report provides global economic forecasts, country-wise growth projections, and policy analysis.
  • In the 2025 edition, India is projected to grow at 6.4%, making it the world‚Äôs fastest-growing major economy.
  • India ranks 4th globally in terms of nominal GDP in 2025, having overtaken Japan, with a GDP of $4.19 trillion.

question: When did India become a member of the International Monetary Fund (IMF)?
solution:
• India became a member of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) on 27th December 1945.
  • India is one of the founding members of the IMF, which was established to promote international monetary cooperation and ensure global financial stability.
  • The IMF was officially created in 1944 during the Bretton Woods Conference, and membership began in 1945.

question: Which two organizations are referred to as the ‚ÄúBretton Woods Twins‚Äù?
option_1: United Nations and World Bank
option_2: International Monetary Fund and World Bank
option_3: International Monetary Fund and United Nations
option_4: World Trade Organization and World Bank
solution:
• The International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank are called the ‚ÄúBretton Woods Twins‚Äù.
  • Both organizations were established in 1944 during the Bretton Woods Conference held in New Hampshire, USA.
  • The conference aimed to create institutions that would ensure global financial stability and promote economic development after World War II.

question: Which group of organizations is collectively known as the World Bank?
option_1: IMF, WTO, UNDP, and OECD
option_2: IBRD, IFC, IDA, ICSID, and MIGA
option_3: IMF, IBRD, WTO, and IDA
option_4: UNDP, IMF, WTO, and ICSID
solution:
• The World Bank is a group of five organizations:
    1. International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD)
    2. International Finance Corporation (IFC)
    3. International Development Association (IDA)
    4. International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID)
    5. Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA)
  • These institutions work together to provide financial and technical assistance to developing countries for economic development and poverty reduction.

question: When was the World Bank officially established?
solution:
• The World Bank was officially established in 1944 at the Bretton Woods Conference held in New Hampshire, USA.
  • Its Articles of Agreement were drafted during this conference.
  • The Bank began operations on June 25, 1946, nearly two years after its founding.
  • Its initial focus was on post-war reconstruction, especially in Europe, and later expanded to global development and poverty reduction.

question: Where is the headquarters of the World Bank located?
solution:
• The headquarters of the World Bank is located in Washington, D.C., USA.
  • It has been headquartered there since its establishment in 1944.
  • Washington, D.C. is also home to the International Monetary Fund (IMF), which is closely associated with the World Bank.

question: Which is the world‚Äôs largest development bank?
option_2: International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD)
solution:
• The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) is the world‚Äôs largest development bank. It has 189 member countries and operates as a global development cooperative. IBRD provides loans, guarantees, advisory services, and risk management products to middle-income and creditworthy low-income countries. More than 60% of its portfolio is focused on middle-income countries. It works only with sovereign governments and sources most of its funds from international financial markets.
  • Asian Development Bank (ADB) focuses on promoting social and economic development in Asia and the Pacific. It has 68 member countries, including 49 from the Asia-Pacific region. ADB provides loans, technical assistance, and grants to its member countries, primarily targeting poverty reduction and sustainable development.
  • New Development Bank (NDB), also known as the BRICS Bank, was established by Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa. It aims to support infrastructure and sustainable development projects in BRICS and other emerging economies. NDB is relatively new compared to IBRD and focuses on complementing existing global financial institutions.
  • European Investment Bank (EIB) is the European Union‚Äôs bank and focuses on financing projects that contribute to EU policy objectives. It provides loans and guarantees for projects within and outside Europe, emphasizing climate action, innovation, and infrastructure development.

question: When was the World Trade Organization (WTO) established?
solution:
• The World Trade Organization (WTO) was officially established on January 1, 1995.
  • It was created under the Marrakesh Agreement, signed in April 1994 by 123 countries.
  • WTO replaced the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), which had governed international trade since 1948.
  • WTO regulates international trade rules and resolves disputes between member nations.

question: The headquarters of the World Trade Organization is located in:
solution:
• The World Trade Organization (WTO) is headquartered in Geneva, Switzerland, at the Centre William Rappard.
  • Geneva is a global center for diplomacy and hosts several major international organizations like WHO, ILO, and UNHRC.
  • WTO‚Äôs headquarters facilitates global trade negotiations, dispute settlements, and policy coordination among its 166 member nations.

question: Which of the following agreements is administered by the WTO?
solution:
• The Agreement on Agriculture (AoA) is administered by the World Trade Organization (WTO) and came into effect in 1995 after the Uruguay Round negotiations.
  • It focuses on three core areas:
    • Market Access ‚Äì reducing tariffs and non-tariff barriers.
    • Domestic Support ‚Äì classifying subsidies into Green, Amber, and Blue Boxes.
    • Export Subsidies ‚Äì reducing trade-distorting export support.
  • The AoA aims to establish a fair and market-oriented agricultural trading system.

üîçOther options:

  • Kyoto Protocol ‚Äì a climate treaty under UNFCCC, targeting greenhouse gas reductions.
  • Paris Agreement ‚Äì a global climate accord under UNFCCC, not related to WTO.
  • Basel Convention ‚Äì governed by UNEP, it regulates hazardous waste movement across borders.

question: Which of the following statements is not correct about the WTO?
option_1: The WTO deals with the global rules of trade between nations.
option_2: It was established as a successor to GATT.
option_3: It is responsible for improving the balance of payments of member countries.
option_4: It provides a framework for negotiating trade agreements.
solution:
• Option (c) is incorrect: The WTO does not directly improve the balance of payments of member countries.
    • However, WTO allows members to impose temporary import restrictions for balance-of-payments reasons under Article XII and XVIII:B of GATT and Article XII of GATS.
    • These provisions are meant to safeguard external financial stability, not to actively manage or improve BOP.
  • Option (a): WTO governs global trade rules, ensuring transparency, fairness, and predictability.
  • Option (b): WTO was established in 1995 as the successor to GATT, expanding its scope to services and intellectual property.
  • Option (d): WTO provides a structured platform for trade negotiations, including multilateral agreements and dispute resolution.

Here‚Äôs your updated bilingual MCQ with rotated answer, criteria for WTO membership, and exam-safe explanation:

question: Which of the following countries is not a member of the WTO?
solution:
• Option (b) is correct (NOT a WTO member):
    • Iran is not a full member of the WTO. It has held observer status since 2005, but its accession process remains incomplete due to political and economic constraints.
  • WTO Membership Criteria:
  • To become a WTO member, a country must:
    • Submit a formal application and a Memorandum on Foreign Trade Regime detailing its trade policies.
    • Undergo scrutiny by a Working Party composed of existing WTO members.
    • Negotiate bilateral trade agreements with interested members.
    • Commit to conforming domestic laws and regulations to WTO rules.
    • Gain consensus approval from all current members.
  • Option (a): India is a founding member of the WTO (since 1995).
  • Option (c): China joined the WTO in December 2001 after a 15-year negotiation.
  • Option (d): Brazil is a founding member and actively participates in WTO negotiations.

question: Along with the World Bank and __________, the WTO is considered the third economic pillar of worldwide dimensions.
solution:
• Option (b) is correct: The World Trade Organization (WTO) is considered the third economic pillar of global governance, alongside the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank (IBRD/IDA).
    • These three institutions collectively manage global trade, monetary stability, and development finance.
    • The IMF focuses on monetary cooperation and financial stability, the World Bank on development and poverty reduction, and the WTO on trade liberalization and dispute resolution.
  • Option (a): The ILO deals with labor standards and rights, not macroeconomic governance.
  • Option (c): The UN is a broader political and humanitarian body, not an economic pillar.
  • Option (d): The World Economic Forum is a non-governmental organization that hosts discussions but has no formal role in global economic governance.

question: After 10 years of deadlock, the European Union (EU) is ready to negotiate with India in the WTO on which issue related to food security?
solution:
• Option (b) is correct: The EU has agreed to negotiate with India on Public Stockholding Norms at the WTO after a decade-long impasse.
    • These norms relate to government procurement and storage of food grains at fixed prices (e.g., Minimum Support Price) for food security and distribution to poor populations.
    • Developed countries argue such programs may exceed WTO subsidy limits, while India insists they are vital for food security and farmer welfare.
    • India seeks a permanent solution to protect these programs from being challenged under WTO rules.
  • Option (a): Agricultural subsidies are a broader issue; the current negotiation is focused specifically on public stockholding.
  • Option (c): Export quotas are not the subject of this negotiation.
  • Option (d): Tariff reductions are part of general trade talks, not the food security-specific deadlock.

question: How many members were part of the WTO as of July 2025?
solution:
• Option (d) is correct: As of July 2025, the World Trade Organization (WTO) has 164 member countries.
    • The European Union also participates as a separate member, making 165 entities in WTO decision-making.
    • WTO membership includes developed, developing, and least-developed countries, ensuring global representation in trade governance.
    • WTO membership reached 164 in 2016 with the accession of Afghanistan, and has remained stable since then.

question: Which event inspired the creation of the United Nations?
solution:
• Option (b) is correct: The United Nations (UN) was created in 1945, inspired by the devastation of World War II.
    • The war exposed the failure of the League of Nations and highlighted the need for a stronger international body to prevent future conflicts.
    • Key milestones included the Declaration of St. James‚Äôs Palace (1941), the Atlantic Charter (1941), and the Declaration by United Nations (1942).
  • Option (a): World War I led to the creation of the League of Nations, not the UN.
  • Option (c): The Cold War influenced UN operations but did not inspire its founding.
  • Option (d): The Korean War occurred after the UN was established.

question: How many permanent members are there in the United Nations Security Council?
solution:
• Option (a) is correct: The United Nations Security Council (UNSC) has 5 permanent members, known as the P5:
    • China, France, Russia, the United Kingdom, and the United States.
    • These members were granted permanent status under the UN Charter of 1945 and possess veto power over substantive resolutions.
  • Option (b): Incorrect‚Äîthere are only 5 permanent members.
  • Option (c): The UNSC has 10 non-permanent members, elected for two-year terms.
  • Option (d): The total number of UNSC members is 15 (5 permanent + 10 non-permanent), not all permanent.

question: Where is the headquarters of the United Nations located?
option_3: New York City, USA
solution:
• Option (c) is correct: The headquarters of the United Nations (UN) is located in New York City, USA, specifically at United Nations Plaza in Manhattan.
    • The complex includes the Secretariat, General Assembly, and Conference buildings, and is considered international territory under a treaty with the U.S. government.
  • Option (a): Geneva hosts a regional UN office, not the main headquarters.
  • Option (b): Paris is home to UNESCO, a specialized agency, not the UN headquarters.
  • Option (d): Vienna also hosts a regional UN office, but not the central headquarters.

question: When was the United Nations Organization (UNO) established?
solution:
• Option (d) is correct: The United Nations Organization (UNO) was officially established on 24 October 1945, after the ratification of the UN Charter by major Allied powers and a majority of signatories.
    • The founding conference was held in San Francisco from 25 April to 26 June 1945, where representatives of 50 countries drafted the Charter.
    • The UN was created to prevent future global conflicts, replacing the League of Nations.
  • Option (a): 1942 marks the Declaration by United Nations, a wartime alliance‚Äînot the founding of the UN.
  • Option (b): 1950 is unrelated to the UN‚Äôs founding.
  • Option (c): 1947 is incorrect; the UN was already functioning by then.

question: How many member states are part of the United Nations at present?
solution:
• Option (b) is correct: As of July 2025, the United Nations (UN) has 193 member states.
    • All members are sovereign states and have equal representation in the UN General Assembly.
    • The most recent member to join was South Sudan in 2011.
  • Option (a), (c), and (d): These figures are incorrect.
    • 195 is often confused with the total number of recognized sovereign states, but not all are UN members.
    • Holy See and Palestine are observer states, not full members.

question: Which of the following is not a principal organ of the United Nations?
option_4: International Court of Justice
solution:
• Option (c) is correct: The World Health Organization (WHO) is not a principal organ of the United Nations.
    • WHO is a specialized agency of the UN, focused on global public health, and operates independently under its own constitution.
  • The six principal organs of the UN, as defined by the UN Charter, are:
    1. General Assembly
    2. Security Council
    3. International Court of Justice (ICJ)
    4. Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC)
    5. Trusteeship Council
    6. Secretariat
  • Option (a), (b), and (d): All are official principal organs of the UN.

question: When did India become a member of the United Nations?
solution:
• Option (d) is correct: India became a founding member of the United Nations on 30 October 1945, shortly after the UN Charter came into force on 24 October 1945.
    • Although India was still under British rule, it was among the original 51 signatories of the UN Charter, signed on 26 June 1945 in San Francisco.
    • India actively participated in early UN efforts on decolonization, peacekeeping, and human rights.
  • Option (a): 1942 marks the Declaration by United Nations, not India‚Äôs membership.
  • Option (b): India was already a member before 1950.
  • Option (c): India gained independence in 1947 but was already a UN member before that.

question: Where is the headquarters of the United Nations International Court of Justice located?
option_3: New York City, USA
solution:
• Option (d) is correct: The International Court of Justice (ICJ) is headquartered at the Peace Palace in The Hague, Netherlands.
    • It is the only principal organ of the UN not located in New York City.
    • The ICJ settles legal disputes between states and provides advisory opinions on international legal questions.
  • Option (a): Geneva hosts several UN agencies but not the ICJ.
  • Option (b): Vienna is home to UN offices, including UNODC and IAEA, but not the ICJ.
  • Option (c): Most UN organs are in New York, but the ICJ is an exception.

question: When was UNESCO founded?
solution: UNESCO (United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization) was founded on 16 November 1945 after World War II to promote international collaboration in education, science, and culture. Its headquarters is located in Paris, France, and it currently has 193 member states.

question: Where is the headquarters of UNESCO located?
solution: UNESCO's headquarters is located in Paris, France. Paris was chosen as the location due to its historical significance and central role in international diplomacy. UNESCO was established in 1945 to promote global collaboration in education, science, and culture.

question: Which of the following is a primary function of UNESCO?
option_1: Managing international financial policies
option_2: Overseeing global health initiatives
option_4: Promoting peace through education, science, and culture
solution: UNESCO's primary function is to promote peace and security through international collaboration in education, science, and culture. It works to improve literacy, protect cultural heritage, and foster scientific advancements globally. UNESCO does not regulate trade, financial policies, or health initiatives, which are functions of other organizations like WTO, IMF, and WHO respectively.

question: Which UNESCO initiative promotes literacy worldwide?
solution: The Education for All (EFA) initiative by UNESCO aims to promote literacy and ensure access to quality education for everyone, especially in underprivileged regions. It was launched in 1990 and focuses on universal primary education, gender equality, and adult literacy. This initiative is a cornerstone of UNESCO's mission to foster global education.

question: How many UNESCO World Heritage Sites are there in India as of 2025?
solution:
As of 2025, India has 44 UNESCO World Heritage Sites, comprising 35 cultural, 7 natural, and 1 mixed site.
  • The first site from India to be inscribed was Ajanta Caves in 1983.
  • The state with the maximum number of sites is Maharashtra, with 6 sites.
  • 43rd site (2024): Moidams of the Ahom Dynasty (Assam) ‚Äî ancient burial mounds reflecting royal funerary architecture.
  • 44th site (2025): Maratha Military Landscapes ‚Äî includes 12 forts across Maharashtra and Tamil Nadu, showcasing strategic hill fort architecture.
  • Significance: UNESCO World Heritage Sites are recognized for their outstanding universal value. They help in preserving cultural and natural heritage, boost tourism, and promote international awareness and cooperation for conservation.

question: Which of the following Indian dance forms is included in UNESCO‚Äôs Intangible Cultural Heritage List?
solution: Chhau is an Indian dance form that is included in UNESCO‚Äôs Intangible Cultural Heritage List. It is a semi-classical dance form that combines martial, tribal, and folk traditions, and is primarily performed in the states of Odisha, Jharkhand, and West Bengal. The dance is known for its vibrant costumes, masks, and storytelling through expressive movements.

question:
Which of the following statements about UNCTAD (United Nations Conference on Trade and Development) is/are correct?
  1. UNCTAD was established in 1946.
  2. Its headquarters is located in Geneva, Switzerland.
  3. UNCTAD has 195 member countries.
  4. UNCTAD focuses on promoting international trade and assisting the Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC) of the United Nations.
option_3: All of the above
solution:
All the statements are correct:
  1. UNCTAD was established in 1946 to address the challenges faced by developing countries in global trade and development.
  2. Its headquarters is located in Geneva, Switzerland, making it a central hub for international trade discussions.
  3. UNCTAD has 195 member countries, which include both developed and developing nations, ensuring a global representation.
  4. UNCTAD focuses on promoting international trade as a means to accelerate development and assists the Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC) of the United Nations in formulating policies for sustainable development.

Important Details about UNCTAD:

  • Reports and Publications: UNCTAD publishes the Trade and Development Report, World Investment Report, and Technology and Innovation Report, which provide insights into global trade, investment trends, and technological advancements.
  • Key Initiatives: UNCTAD works on issues like debt management, digital economy, e-commerce, and trade facilitation for developing countries.
  • Role in SDGs: UNCTAD plays a crucial role in achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) by addressing trade inequalities and fostering inclusive economic growth.
  • Conferences: The UNCTAD conference is held every four years to set priorities and review global trade and development policies.

question: When was the Asian Development Bank (ADB) established?
solution: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) was established in 1966 to foster economic growth and cooperation in the Asia-Pacific region. Its headquarters is located in Mandaluyong, Metro Manila, Philippines. ADB provides financial assistance, technical expertise, and policy advice to its member countries to promote sustainable development and reduce poverty.

question: Which of the following countries is not a member of the Asian Development Bank?
solution: Russia is not a member of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). ADB primarily focuses on the Asia-Pacific region, and its members include countries like Japan, India, and Australia. Russia, being outside this regional framework, is not part of ADB.

question: Who is the President of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) as of August 2025?
solution: As of August 2025, the President of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) is Masato Kanda. He officially assumed office on February 24, 2025, becoming the 11th President of ADB. Kanda succeeded Masatsugu Asakawa and brings nearly four decades of experience in international finance, having previously served as Japan‚Äôs Vice-Minister of Finance for International Affairs.

question: How much investment did the ADB President announce for India‚Äôs urban transformation in 2025?
solution: In May 2025, ADB President Masato Kanda announced a $10 billion plan to support India‚Äôs urban transformation over the next five years. The initiative includes metro expansions, regional rapid transit systems (RRTS), and urban infrastructure upgrades across 100 cities. It blends sovereign loans, private financing, and third-party capital, anchored by India‚Äôs Urban Challenge Fund (UCF).

question: What is the full form of SAARC?
option_1: South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation
option_2: South Asian Alliance for Regional Collaboration
option_3: South Asian Assembly for Regional Cooperation
option_4: South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation
solution: The full form of SAARC is South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation. It is an organization of eight South Asian nations established in 1985 to promote economic and regional integration. Member countries include India, Pakistan, Nepal, Bhutan, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Maldives, and Afghanistan.

question: Where is the headquarters of SAARC located?
solution: The headquarters of SAARC (South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation) is located in Kathmandu, Nepal. It was established in 1985, and Kathmandu serves as the central hub for coordinating activities among the eight member nations.

question: Where is the South Asian University, jointly established by eight SAARC member states, situated?
solution: The South Asian University, jointly established by the eight SAARC member states, is located in New Delhi, India. It was founded in 2010 to promote regional cooperation and provide world-class education to students from SAARC countries.
